author: karalabe
content: Just a heads up that we're seeing some weird things on Rinkeby

author: karalabe
content: Lots and lots of txs are piled up but are not mined

author: karalabe
content: Figured it out, it's a "transition" issue. Our miners accepted 1gwei txs. When London passed, the 1gwei "total" became `1gwei - eps` tip, which was less than the miner wants, but we don't have an eviction in place for this transition

author: karalabe
content: So the 1gwei-7wei basefee txs remained in the pool but were rejected by the miner, everything afterwards piling up

author: holgerd77
content:
One suggestion I have: we at EthereumJS are always very thankful for some lightweight test network where it's easy to connect to without the hazzle of a long sync, I could imagine that this is also the case for various teams/devs within the ecosystem (unproven though, might be a case for a question by <@!420951281910284289>).

Would it be a way to just always keep the last ephemeral network set  up (in this case: `calaveras`) until the next HF (and then replace by the last `shanghai` network and so on) and somewhat better document that and add this as an additional test network layer in addition to the existing heavier weight networks?

This *will* come with some extra administration effort, but I would assume this could be valuable to the community.

author: holgerd77
content: We now have got our **final EthereumJS London releases** (VM, Tx, other) out including the finalized block numbers:  https://github.com/ethereumjs/ethereumjs-monorepo/releases

author: timbeiko
content: We could, but isn't one of the challenges that the network will start taking a while to sync to if we leave it on too long ðŸ˜… ?

content: <@552133098075193354> for a let's say a HF to HF period of three months block numbers would go up to numbers of ~500.000, that would still be in another league (factor 10x) than even the youngest major test network Goerli with its 5Mio+ blocks.
